Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial of Ultrasound Technology in Therapeutic Applications

Trial_Design.evidence: This randomised controlled trial was conducted in a clinical setting.

Participants.evidence: Participants were eligible if they had musculoskeletal or tumor conditions.

Intervention.evidence: The intervention group received ultrasound therapy, while the control group received standard care.

Objective.evidence: This study assesses its efficacy in enhancing drug delivery and therapeutic outcomes.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the enhancement of drug delivery, measured over a 6-month period.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was computer-generated, with allocation concealment using sealed envelopes.

Blinding.evidence: Blinding was applied to outcome assessors, patients, and clinicians.

Number_Randomised.evidence: A total of 200 participants were randomised: 100 to the intervention and 100 to the control group, between January 2020 and June 2021.

Number_Analysed.evidence: Analysis included 98 participants in the intervention group and 97 in the control group, using an intention-to-treat approach.

Result_Outcome.evidence: The intervention group showed a significant improvement in drug delivery (mean difference = 5.2, 95% CI 3.1 to 7.3; p = 0.01).

Harms.evidence: Adverse events were mild, with 3% in the intervention group and 1% in the control group experiencing side effects.

Funding.evidence: This trial was funded by the National Institutes of Health.
